title: WFTDA Library
description:
The game of Flat Track Roller Derby is played on a flat, oval track. Play is broken up into two 30-minute periods, and within those periods, into units of play called “$Jams:jam$,” which last up to two minutes. There are 30 seconds between each $Jam:jam$.

During a $Jam:jam$, each team fields up to five Skaters. Four of these Skaters are called “$Blockers:blocker$” (together, the $Blockers:blocker$ are called the “$Pack:pack$”), and one is called a “$Jammer:jammer$.” The $Jammer:jammer$ wears a helmet cover with a $star:the-star$ on it.

The two $Jammers:jammer$ start each $Jam:jam$ $behind:behind$ the $Pack:pack$, and score a point for every opposing $Blocker:blocker$ they $lap:lapping$, each $lap:lapping$. Because they start $behind:behind$ the $Pack:pack$, they must get through the $Pack:pack$, then all the way around the track to be eligible to score points on opposing $Blockers:blocker$.

Roller derby is a full-contact sport; however, Skaters cannot use their heads, elbows, forearms, hands, knees, lower legs, or feet to make contact to opponents. Skaters cannot make contact to opponents’ heads, backs, knees, lower legs, or feet.

Play that is unsafe or illegal may result in a Skater being assessed a $penalty:penalty$, which is served by $sitting:sitting$ in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box for 30 seconds of $Jam:jam$ time.

The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.

A common $Jam:jam$ might go like this:

1. $Blockers:blocker$ line up $behind:behind$ the $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ Line and in front of the $Jammer:jammer$ Line.
2. $Jammers:jammer$ line up $behind:behind$ the $Jammer:jammer$ Line.
3. At the $Jam:jam$-Starting Whistle, the $Blockers:blocker$ skate forward and compete for superior position. The $Jammers:jammer$ skate forward and try to get through the $Pack:pack$. Each $Blocker:blocker$ simultaneously tries to prevent the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ from getting past, and to help their own $Jammer:jammer$ get through.
4. One $Jammer:jammer$ exits the $Pack:pack$ and is declared $Lead Jammer:lead-jammer$, earning the right to end the $Jam:jam$ when they decide. This $Jammer:jammer$ races around the track to get into scoring position.
5. The same $Jammer:jammer$ begins to work their way through the $Pack:pack$ for the second time, and the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ makes their way out of the $Pack:pack$ for the first time.
6. As the second $Jammer:jammer$ to escape the $Pack:pack$ comes around into scoring position, the first $Jammer:jammer$ calls off the $Jam:jam$.
7. The first $Jammer:jammer$ has scored points (up to four), and held their opponent at zero points. Meanwhile, the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ (by getting into scoring position) held the first $Jammer:jammer$ at only those points, as they could have scored more points on subsequent $passes:earned-pass$.

documents.title: Rules
documents.description:
The game of Flat Track Roller Derby is played on a flat, oval track. Play is broken up into two 30-minute periods, and within those periods, into units of play called “$Jams:jam$,” which last up to two minutes. There are 30 seconds between each $Jam:jam$.

During a $Jam:jam$, each team fields up to five Skaters. Four of these Skaters are called “$Blockers:blocker$” (together, the $Blockers:blocker$ are called the “$Pack:pack$”), and one is called a “$Jammer:jammer$.” The $Jammer:jammer$ wears a helmet cover with a $star:the-star$ on it.

The two $Jammers:jammer$ start each $Jam:jam$ $behind:behind$ the $Pack:pack$, and score a point for every opposing $Blocker:blocker$ they $lap:lapping$, each $lap:lapping$. Because they start $behind:behind$ the $Pack:pack$, they must get through the $Pack:pack$, then all the way around the track to be eligible to score points on opposing $Blockers:blocker$.

Roller derby is a full-contact sport; however, Skaters cannot use their heads, elbows, forearms, hands, knees, lower legs, or feet to make contact to opponents. Skaters cannot make contact to opponents’ heads, backs, knees, lower legs, or feet.

Play that is unsafe or illegal may result in a Skater being assessed a $penalty:penalty$, which is served by $sitting:sitting$ in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box for 30 seconds of $Jam:jam$ time.

The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.

A common $Jam:jam$ might go like this:

1. $Blockers:blocker$ line up $behind:behind$ the $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ Line and in front of the $Jammer:jammer$ Line.
2. $Jammers:jammer$ line up $behind:behind$ the $Jammer:jammer$ Line.
3. At the $Jam:jam$-Starting Whistle, the $Blockers:blocker$ skate forward and compete for superior position. The $Jammers:jammer$ skate forward and try to get through the $Pack:pack$. Each $Blocker:blocker$ simultaneously tries to prevent the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ from getting past, and to help their own $Jammer:jammer$ get through.
4. One $Jammer:jammer$ exits the $Pack:pack$ and is declared $Lead Jammer:lead-jammer$, earning the right to end the $Jam:jam$ when they decide. This $Jammer:jammer$ races around the track to get into scoring position.
5. The same $Jammer:jammer$ begins to work their way through the $Pack:pack$ for the second time, and the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ makes their way out of the $Pack:pack$ for the first time.
6. As the second $Jammer:jammer$ to escape the $Pack:pack$ comes around into scoring position, the first $Jammer:jammer$ calls off the $Jam:jam$.
7. The first $Jammer:jammer$ has scored points (up to four), and held their opponent at zero points. Meanwhile, the opposing $Jammer:jammer$ (by getting into scoring position) held the first $Jammer:jammer$ at only those points, as they could have scored more points on subsequent $passes:earned-pass$.

sections.title: Timing
sections.description:
**A game lasts for 60 minutes of play, divided into two 30-minute periods with a halftime between them.** Periods are broken into $Jams:jam$, which are the basic unit of play for roller derby.

**A $Jam:jam$ can last up to two minutes.** $Jams:jam$ may be called off prior to two minutes as part of gameplay, as described below. Each $Jam:jam$ starts with a single short whistle blast, and finishes at the end of a series of four short whistle blasts. At least 30 seconds must elapse between $Jams:jam$. More than 30 seconds may not elapse unless a timeout is called.

**A period starts on the $Jam:jam$-Starting Whistle of the first $Jam:jam$ for that period.** The period clock does not $stop:stopped$ between $Jams:jam$ unless a timeout is called. If the period clock reaches zero before the next $Jam:jam$ has started, the period ends at that moment; otherwise, the period ends at the conclusion of the final $Jam:jam$ for the period.

If a $Jam:jam$ is called off due to officiating discretion (see Section 5.2) or there is an officiating error that potentially impacted the outcome (as in winner/loser) of the game, and there are less than 30 seconds remaining on the period clock at the end of the game (including when the period clock has expired), an additional $Jam:jam$ may be run at the discretion of the $Head Referee:head-referee$. This additional $Jam:jam$ will have the same form (Overtime or not; see Section 1.5.1) as the $Jam:jam$ that ended and be part of the same period.

sections.title: Teams
sections.description:
**A team is comprised of Skaters, who must be uniquely identified by a $roster:roster$ number.** Each team must have a jersey of the same base color, such that uniform colors of the two teams playing are of high contrast. $Roster:roster$ numbers must be clearly displayed on a Skater’s back and upper arm areas. Each team must have helmet covers to clearly indicate who their $Jammer:jammer$ and $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ are. The $Jammer:jammer$ and $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ helmet covers for the two teams must be easy to differentiate.

**Skaters must wear quad-style roller skates and $protective gear:protective-gear$ during play.** Inline skates are not permitted. $Protective gear:protective-gear$ may not be removed during play. $Protective gear:protective-gear$ may not impair or interfere with the safety or play of other Skaters, support staff, or Officials.

**Skaters who are injured during play may return to play as long as they are no longer apparently injured or bleeding.** A Skater whose injury alters the flow of the game (examples include a $Jam:jam$ being called off, a period clock stoppage, or a $substitute:substitution$ being $seated:sitting$ in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box) may not participate during the following three $Jams:jam$ (extending into the following period if necessary). A Skater whose injury alters the flow of the game more than once in a period may not participate as a Skater for the rest of that period. The $Head Referee:head-referee$ may also declare that a team has forfeited the game if that team has five or fewer Skaters eligible to participate, or refuses to field Skaters on the track to continue play.

sections.title: Timeouts
sections.description:
**Teams and Officials may {stop} the period clock by calling a timeout.** Timeouts may only be called between $Jams:jam$, though Officials may end a $Jam:jam$ in order to call an Official Timeout. The beginning of a timeout is marked by four short whistle blasts, and the end of a timeout is marked by a long rolling whistle, after which the next $Jam:jam$ begins as soon as possible if there is time remaining on the period clock. At most, 30 seconds may $pass:earned-pass$ before the next $Jam:jam$ begins. The period clock starts again at the $Jam:jam$-Starting Whistle.

There are three types of timeouts.

section.title: Team Timeouts
section.description: **Each team has three timeouts that they can take during the game.** Team Timeouts may be requested only by the team’s Captain or Designated Alternate. Penalized Captains or Designated Alternates cannot request a Team Timeout. Team Timeouts last for 60 seconds.

section.title: Official Reviews
section.description:
**Each team begins the period with one Official Review** which they may use during that period. An Official Review is a formal request made by a team’s Captain or Designated Alternate for Officials to review a specific officiating decision. The only officiating decisions that can be the subject of an Official Review are those made during the prior Jam, or during the lineup time preceding the prior Jam. The Head Referee investigates the review with other Officials, and uses the information gathered to render a decision on the item under review, as well as related decisions. The Head Referee then announces their findings and any changes that result from the review to both teams’ representatives. This decision is final and not reviewable.

If the Head Referee determines that an officiating error was made in relation to the situation under review, the team will retain the privilege to call an additional review later in the same period. The review can be retained in this manner only once per period.

A team may also elect to use their Official Review as a Team Timeout. In this case, the review will not be retained. Penalized Captains or Designated Alternates cannot request an Official Review.

Official Reviews (whether unused or retained) are not carried forward to the subsequent period.

section.title: Official Timeouts
section.description: **Officials may take a timeout in order to ensure that the game is running smoothly and correctly.** If the prior Jam ended with less than 30 seconds on the period clock, the fact that the Officials called a timeout will not necessarily result in another Jam occurring in the same manner that a Team Timeout or Official Review would. Instead, the Officials must determine whether or not there is reason to hold another Jam for that period. If the Officials determine that there is no reason to hold another Jam, both teams must be given a chance to call a Team Timeout or Official Review (if they have any remaining). If they decline, the period will end.

sections.title: Game Information
sections.description:
**Critical game information must be displayed in a manner that is highly visible to Teams, Officials, and spectators.** This displayed critical game information is considered official, and must include, at a minimum:

- The period clock
- The $Jam:jam$ clock
- The Official Score

Errors in timing or score should be updated as quickly as possible. If an error persists for an extended period of time, it should be corrected only if the correction itself would have minimal impact on the game.

sections.title: Winning
sections.description: **The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.**

sections.title: Overtime
sections.description:
**If the game ends with the score tied, the second period will be extended by at least one additional $Jam:jam$.** This Overtime $Jam:jam$ is like any other $Jam:jam$, with two exceptions:

- No $Lead Jammer:lead-jammer$ is declared
- Both $Jammers:jammer$ begin scoring on their first $trip through the Pack:trip-through-the-pack$ (each $Jammer:jammer$ is $in position:in-position$ to $lap:lapping$ the opposing $Blockers:blocker$ on their first $earned pass:earned-pass$ of those $Blockers:blocker$)

More $Jams:jam$ will be added in this manner until a $Jam:jam$ ends with the score no longer tied.

entries.title: Trip Through the Pack
entries.description: $Jammers:jammer$ make $trips through the Pack:trip-through-the-pack$. Each $trip:trip-through-the-pack$ represents an opportunity to score points on opponents. (See Section 3).

entries.title: Passing the Star / Star Pass
entries.description: The act of transferring $Jammer:jammer$ status, which is accomplished by the $Jammer:jammer$ handing their helmet cover ($the Star:the-star$) to the $Pivot:pivot-blocker$.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Passing the Star \/ Star Pass|pass the star|passes the star|passed the star|passing the star|star pass|star passing|star passes|star-pass|star-passing|star-passes)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Re-Pass
entries.description: The act of $passing:earned-pass$ an opponent who has already been $passed:earned-pass$ during the current $lap:lapping$. Most relevant to a $Jammer:jammer$ who ends up $ahead:ahead$ of an opponent without “earning” the $pass:earned-pass$. Such a $Jammer:jammer$ would not score a point on that opponent, but could $re-pass:re-pass$ that opponent, earning their second $pass:earned-pass$, in order to score that point.

entries.title: Pivot Blocker (Pivot)
entries.description: A $Blocker:blocker$ with extra abilities and responsibilities, commonly referred to as the $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ (see Section 2.2.3).

entries.title: Pack Skater
entries.description: Any $Blocker:blocker$ who is part of a legally defined $Pack:pack$.

entries.title: No Pack
entries.description: When there is not a group of $Blockers:blocker$ (from both teams) skating within 10 ft (3.05 m) of each other, or when there are two or more equally numbered groups of $Blockers:blocker$ not skating within 10 ft (3.05 m) of each other.

entries.title: Lead Jammer
entries.description: The $Lead Jammer:lead-jammer$ is the first $Jammer:jammer$ to establish superior position to the foremost $in-play:in-play$ $Blocker:blocker$, having already earned a $pass:earned-pass$ on all $Blockers:blocker$ excluding those $ahead:ahead$ of the $Engagement Zone:engagement-zone$.

entries.title: Actively Absorbing
entries.description: Any movement toward oncoming contact intended only to protect the recipient of the contact.

entries.title: Ahead
entries.description: One thing (for example, a Skater, a line, the $Pack:pack$) is “$ahead:ahead$” of another thing, in relation to the track, if it is nearer in the counterclockwise direction than the clockwise direction.

entries.title: Apex Jump
entries.description: An attempt to legally shorten the distance travelled around the curve of the track by leaping over the track boundary and landing back $in bounds:in-bounds$.

entries.title: Assist
entries.description: Physically affecting a teammate. Common examples include a push or a whip.

entries.title: Behind
entries.description: One thing (for example, a Skater, a line, the $Pack:pack$) is “$behind:behind$” another thing, in relation to the track, if it is nearer in the clockwise direction than the counterclockwise direction.

entries.title: Blocker
entries.description: The positional Skaters who form the $Pack:pack$. Up to four $Blockers:blocker$ from each team may skate, per $Jam:jam$. One $Blocker:blocker$ per $Jam:jam$, for each team, may be a $Pivot Blocker:pivot-blocker$.

entries.title: Blocking Zones
entries.description: Areas of the body that may be used to hit an opponent when performing a block.

entries.title: Captain
entries.description: The Skater identified, via a visible “C” on their body or clothing, to speak on the team’s behalf. If one has not been selected or has left the game, the team may determine one at any time by informing the $Head Referee:head-referee$, and must determine one if necessary (for example, if a $penalty:penalty$ is to be assessed to a $Captain:captain$, the team must determine a $Captain:captain$).

entries.title: Counter-Block
entries.description: Any motion/movement toward an oncoming block by the receiving opponent designed to counteract an opponent’s block. $Counter-blocking:counter-block$ is treated as blocking and held to the same standards and rules (except where specified). Continued engagement which goes beyond countering the initial effect of the opponent’s block should be considered a separate block, and judged separately.

entries.title: Designated Alternate
entries.description: The $Captain:captain$ designates an additional person to act on their team’s behalf via a visible “A” on their uniform or body; this person is the $Designated Alternate:designated-alternate$. The $Designated Alternate:designated-alternate$ may be a teammate, coach, or manager. A team may only have one $Designated Alternate:designated-alternate$. If one has not been selected or has left the game, the $Captain:captain$ may designate a different Alternate by informing the $Head Referee:head-referee$.

entries.title: Down
entries.description: A Skater is $down:down$ when part of the Skater’s body or equipment (aside from skates) is touching the floor. A Skater whose only contact with the floor (aside from skates) is one hand is not considered $down:down$. Once $down:down$, a Skater is considered $down:down$ until the Skater is $standing:standing$, stepping, or skating.

entries.title: Pass/Earned Pass
entries.description: See Section 2.5

entries.title: Engagement Zone
entries.description: The zone in which $Blockers:blocker$ are $in play:in-play$ and may legally $engage:engaging$ and be $engaged:engaging$. The $Engagement Zone:engagement-zone$ extends from 20 ft (6.10 m) $behind:behind$ the rearmost $Pack Skater:pack-skater$ to 20 ft (6.10 m) in front of the foremost $Pack Skater:pack-skater$, between the inside and outside track boundaries.

entries.title: Engaging
entries.description: Any sort of interaction with another Skater on the track during a $Jam:jam$ (see also $assist:assist$ and blocking, Section 2.4).

entries.title: Established Position
entries.description: Where a Skater is physically; an area of the track where the Skater has secured their place. Examples include up, $in bounds:in-bounds$, $down:down$, $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$, $in play:in-play$, and $out of play:out-of-play$.

entries.title: Exiting the Track
entries.description: ($Penalty:penalty$ Enforcement) $Exiting the track:exiting-the-track$ to the outside in order to report to the $Penalty:penalty$ Box.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Exiting the Track|exit the track|exits the track)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Expulsion
entries.description: Removal by the $Head Referee:head-referee$ of a Skater or Team Staff from the remainder of the game for a serious illegal action, such as physical violence or any action deemed by the Officials to cause an extraordinary physical threat to others.

entries.title: Falling Small
entries.description: A Skater is said to have “fallen small” if they fall with the arms and legs controlled, tucked into the body, and not flailing or sprawled.

entries.title: Forceful Contact
entries.description: Abrupt contact (such as hitting or striking) with a significant amount of strength and energy or any contact that either has the potential to harm the recipient or significantly alter their position, balance, speed, trajectory, etc. (regardless of whether that potential is actualized).

entries.title: Fouling Out
entries.description: Removal, by an Official, of a Skater from the remainder of the game for having seven $penalties:penalty$ recorded for that Skater.

entries.title: Governing Body
entries.description: The organization responsible for the sanctioning of the game; or in an unsanctioned game, the organization responsible for determining the terms of the game, such as a tournament, local league, or other person(s) serving in that role.

entries.title: Grasping
entries.description: Actively gripping something; for example, grabbing a teammate’s uniform or helmet cover, or holding hands. The $grasping:grasping$ Skater’s arm, from the hand up to (but not including) the shoulder, is considered to be part of the “$grasp:grasping$.” The teammate is not considered part of the $grasp:grasping$, unless the teammate is independently $grasping:grasping$.

entries.title: Head Referee
entries.description: One Referee will be designated the $Head Referee:head-referee$. The $Head Referee:head-referee$ is the ultimate authority of the game.

entries.title: Hips
entries.description: The laterally-projecting prominence of the pelvis or pelvic region from the waist to the thigh. The central point of this area determines a $pass:earned-pass$, regardless of the direction the Skater is facing.

entries.title: Illegal Procedure
entries.description: Any technical (non-contact) infraction that violates the rules.

entries.title: Immediately
entries.description: The first legal opportunity in which someone may complete an action.

entries.title: Impeding
entries.description: Actions that restrict an opponent’s speed and/or trajectory in any direction on the track.

entries.title: Impenetrable
entries.description: A wall is considered to be $impenetrable:impenetrable$ from a certain direction when, to achieve a $pass:earned-pass$ on one or more of the Skaters who comprise the wall, an opponent would need to physically break bones or joints. The parts that would need to be physically broken in order to $pass:earned-pass$ are considered the “$impenetrable:impenetrable$” parts. For example, if two teammates are skating forward with their arms around each other’s backs, the arms constitute an $impenetrable:impenetrable$ wall, so that an opponent could not $pass:earned-pass$ between the pair without breaking one of those $Blockers:blocker$’ arms.

entries.title: In Bounds
entries.description: A Skater is $in bounds:in-bounds$ if the only points at which they are touching the floor are on or in between the track boundary lines. Once touching beyond the track boundary, a Skater is considered to be $in bounds:in-bounds$ again once all parts of the Skater that are touching the floor are on or between the track boundary lines. A Skater who touches the floor beyond the track boundary with only one arm or hand is still considered $in bounds:in-bounds$ (see also $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$, $straddling:straddling$).

entries.title: In Play
entries.description: A $Blocker:blocker$ is $in play:in-play$ when they are $in bounds:in-bounds$ and $upright:upright$ within the $Engagement Zone:engagement-zone$. $Jammers:jammer$ who are $in bounds:in-bounds$ and $upright:upright$ are always $in play:in-play$.

entries.title: In Position
entries.description: A Skater is $in position:in-position$ when they are on the track, $in bounds:in-bounds$, and in the designated area for their position when the $Jam:jam$-Starting Whistle is blown.

entries.title: In Queue
entries.description: Actively skating while having a $penalty:penalty$ pending, usually after having been waved back to the track due to the $Penalty:penalty$ Box being full, or having been assessed a $penalty:penalty$ while being the only $Blocker:blocker$ on the track.

entries.title: Initiator
entries.description:
The Skater who is responsible for contact happening to an opponent (initiating a block) or teammate (initiating an $assist:assist$). A Skater can also initiate their own $assist:assist$ by taking a whip off of a teammate’s body, or initiate a $counter-block:counter-block$ in response to an opponent’s block. The $initiator:initiator$ of a block or $assist:assist$ is always responsible for the legality of the contact.

After a $counter-block:counter-block$, continued engagement by the $counter-blocking:counter-block$ skater should be considered a new action, with the skater responsible for the continued contact considered the $initiator:initiator$. The legality of this action should be judged separately from the initial block and $counter-block:counter-block$.

entries.title: Insubordination
entries.description: Willfully or neglectfully failing to comply with an Official’s orders. Wrongful or improper behavior motivated by intentional disregard for the rules.

entries.title: Jam
entries.description: The basic unit of play for the game. A $Jam:jam$ can last up to two minutes.

entries.title: Jammer
entries.description: The point scorer for a team.

entries.title: Lap/Lapping
entries.description: One Skater has $lapped:lapping$ an opponent if the Skater has $passed:earned-pass$ the opponent twice in a row without the opponent having $passed:earned-pass$ the $lapping:lapping$ Skater in between. If a $Jammer:jammer$ $passes:earned-pass$ an opponent for the second time, but the second $pass:earned-pass$ was not “earned,” the $Jammer:jammer$ is still said to have $lapped:lapping$ their opponent, and may earn a “$re-pass:re-pass$” on said opponent to score the missed point.

entries.title: Linking
entries.description: Interlocking of arms via crooking of an elbow. Both Skaters’ arms, up to (but not including) the shoulder are considered to be part of the $link:linking$.

entries.title: No Impact
entries.description: A violation of the rules of the game that has limited impact on safety or gameplay, and does not warrant a $penalty:penalty$.

entries.title: Not-On-the-Track (NOTT) Point
entries.description: A point given for an opponent who is not on the track (such as Skaters in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box) that the $Jammer:jammer$ earns $immediately:immediately$ upon earning a $pass:earned-pass$ on any opposing $Blocker:blocker$, per $trip through the Pack:trip-through-the-pack$.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Not-On-the-Track \17NOTT\22 Point|NOTT point|not-on-the-track point|not on the track point)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Out of Bounds
entries.description: A Skater is $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$ when part of the Skater’s body or equipment is touching the floor beyond the track boundary. One arm or hand touching the floor beyond the track boundary does not render a Skater $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$ (see also $in bounds:in-bounds$, $straddling:straddling$).

entries.title: Out of Play
entries.description: A $Blocker:blocker$ who is $in bounds:in-bounds$, but positioned outside of the $Engagement Zone:engagement-zone$. If $no Pack:no-pack$ is defined, all $Blockers:blocker$ are $out of play:out-of-play$. When a $Jammer:jammer$ is $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$, they are $out of play:out-of-play$.

entries.title: Pack
entries.description: The largest group of in-bounds $Blockers:blocker$, skating or $standing:standing$ in proximity (within 10 ft [3.05 m]), containing members from both teams. The $Jammers:jammer$ are independent of this definition.

entries.title: Penalty
entries.description: A violation of the rules of the game requiring the Skater to serve time in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box, or the specific punishment of serving time in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box due to the commission of such a violation.

entries.title: Points Awarded in Error
entries.description: Points that have not been legally earned by a $Jammer:jammer$ and have been awarded to the team incorrectly and/or erroneously by an Official or as the result of a technology malfunction.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Points Awarded in Error|point awarded in error|points awarded-in-error|point awarded-in-error)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Points Denied in Error
entries.description: Similar to $points awarded in error:points-awarded-in-error$, $points denied in error:points-denied-in-error$ are points that have been legally earned by a $Jammer:jammer$ but have not been added to the Official Score due to delay, an error by an Official, or as the result of a technology malfunction.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Points Denied in Error|point denied in error|points denied-in-error|point denied-in-error)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Positional Blocking
entries.description: Blocking without contact; positioning oneself so as to $impede:impeding$ an opponent’s movement on the track. $Positional blocking:positional-blocking$ need not be intentional.
entries.regExp: /([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|^)(Positional Blocking|positional block|positional blocks|positionally block|positionally blocks|positionally blocked|positionally blocking)([\s\,\.\!\-\(\)\'\"\“\”\’]|$)/gi

entries.title: Protective Gear
entries.description: Skaters must wear helmet, mouthguard, wrist guards, elbow pads, and knee pads so long as they provide additional protection and the Skater is physically able to wear them. Skaters shall not be penalized if the equipment does not provide additional protection for the Skater.

entries.title: Relative Position
entries.description: A Skater’s location, when $in bounds:in-bounds$ and $upright:upright$, in relation to other Skaters involved in the action. $Relative position:relative-position$ is said to be “gained” or “lost” if said location changes in a way that gives or loses some advantage (for example, one Skater $passing:earned-pass$ another, or being knocked $down:down$, $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$, or $out of play:out-of-play$). $Relative position:relative-position$ is only measured in the counterclockwise direction.

entries.title: Roster
entries.description: The list of Skaters for a team, and their identifying numbers, who are eligible to play in the game.

entries.title: Sitting
entries.description: A Skater whose buttocks are in full contact with the seat of a chair or bench.

entries.title: Skating – Direction of Travel
entries.description: A Skater’s direction of travel (for example, counterclockwise, lateral, or clockwise) is measured by the skates moving relative to a line perpendicular to the inside track boundary. If the skates are moving in opposite directions, direction of travel is determined by the $hips:hips$.

entries.title: Standing
entries.description: A Skater holding their body weight on their skates, such that they are not $down:down$ and it is obvious to Officials, Skaters, and spectators that they are not $sitting:sitting$.

entries.title: Stopped
entries.description: A Skater not making any directional movement with their skates.

entries.title: Straddling
entries.description: A Skater is $straddling:straddling$ when they are simultaneously touching the floor on or between the track boundary lines and beyond the track boundary. Touching the floor beyond the track boundary with only one arm or hand does not render a Skater $straddling:straddling$. $Straddling:straddling$ Skaters are considered $out of bounds:out-of-bounds$, except where otherwise noted (see also $in bounds:in-bounds$).

entries.title: Substitution
entries.description: Replacing a Skater on the track or in the $Penalty:penalty$ Box with a teammate.

entries.title: Target Zones
entries.description: Areas of the body on an opponent that a Skater makes contact to when blocking.

entries.title: The Star
entries.description: The $Jammer:jammer$ helmet cover, which has two stars on it, one on each side.

entries.title: The Stripe
entries.description: The $Pivot:pivot-blocker$ helmet cover, which has one long $stripe:the-stripe$ $down:down$ the middle of it.

entries.title: Upright
entries.description: Any Skater who is not considered $down:down$.

entries.title: Warning
entries.description: A formal verbal indication from the Official that play is currently or is about to be improper, so that a Skater can take corrective action.
